                        tabs: [{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_0","title":"New - COVID-19 Update 4/28/20","content":"Dear Families,
\n
\nWe are fortunate to have partnerships with many outstanding businesses, organizations, and community groups in our area. This has become even more evident during the current situation. To support our community during this time, our partners at LOC Federal Credit Union are launching a series of webinars around various financial topics. The first webinar will take place on Thursday, May 7, from 6 p.m. to 7 p.m. and will focus on budgeting. These events are free and open to everyone. To learn more, please visit https://bit.ly/35be94K.  
\n
\nOperations Staff Performing Grounds Work 
\nThis week our maintenance and grounds crews will begin our lawn mowing rotation. This type of work is allowed under the current Stay at Home order and is necessary to maintain our school grounds. Our employees will be following social distancing guidelines while they are at work. 
\n
\nMeal Distribution and Delivery
\nOur next meal kit distribution is scheduled for Monday, May 4. The distribution will take place from 4 p.m. to 6 p.m. in the circle drive on the north side of Howell High School. For families who lack transportation to pick up a meal kit, delivery will be available. To request delivery, please visit http://bit.ly/2vZoHa2. All requests for delivery will need to be submitted by 2 p.m. on Sunday, May 3. This will allow our Food Service and Transportation Departments to plan for the deliveries. 
\n
\nBegindergarten/Kindergarten and New Student Registration
\nWhile our Registration Office is currently closed, you may still register incoming begindergarten and kindergarten students online at HowellSchools.com/KDG. Additionally, new students can be enrolled at HowellSchools.com/Enroll. On these sites, you can complete all of the registration forms. When our Registration Office re-opens, we will work to collect the documents required to complete the registration process. 
\n
\nTech Support and Loaner Devices
\nIf your family is in need of a device for remote learning or if you have other technology-related questions, support is available by calling 314-635-0638 Monday through Friday between 9:00 a.m. - 4:00 p.m. We ask that you only request a loaner device if your family is truly in need of one so that we can distribute devices as quickly and efficiently as possible to those who do not currently have a home device. Following the Governor's Stay at Home Order, technology support is only available remotely.
\n
\nSincerely,
\nErin J. MacGregor, Ed.S.
\nSuperintendent
\nHowell Public Schools","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_1","title":"COVID-19 Update 4/23/20 5:45 p.m.","content":"Dear Families,
\n
\nI want to extend a big congratulations to Howell High School Junior Kirsten Smith, who won the Best Use of Color Award in the 2020 North American International Auto Show Poster Contest. This is Kirsten's second time earning honors in the poster contest. Last year she won second place in the tenth-grade category. Kirsten's design features the Detroit skyline in warm and cool colors to signify the auto show's schedule change from January to June. You can read more about this honor and view Kirsten's design at https://bit.ly/2zkJmGB. 
\n
\nMeal Distribution Returns to Howell High School 
\nOn Monday, April 27, the district’s Food Service Department will resume distributing meal kits from 4 p.m. to 6 p.m. in the circle drive on the north side of Howell High School. Meal distribution will take place every Monday through June 1. For families who lack transportation to pick up a meal kit, delivery will be available. To request delivery, please visit http://bit.ly/2vZoHa2. All requests for delivery will need to be submitted weekly and must be received by 2 p.m. on Sunday. This will allow our Food Service and Transportation Departments to plan for the deliveries. 
\n
\nTechnology Support
\nIf your family is in need of a device for remote learning or if you have other technology-related questions, support is available by calling 314-635-0638 Monday through Friday between 9:00 a.m. - 4:00 p.m. We ask that you only request a loaner device if your family is truly in need of one so that we can distribute devices as quickly and efficiently as possible to those who do not currently have a home device. Following the Governor's Stay at Home Order, technology support is only available remotely.
\n
\nPandemic Electronic Benefit Transfer Program
\nThe Pandemic Electronic Benefit Transfer Program (P-EBT) will provide food assistance to families of students ages five-eighteen who receive free or reduced-price school meals. Qualifying families will receive $193.80 per child for the months of March and April, and $182.40 per child for the months of May and June combined. Families who already receive free or reduced-price school meals have been identified by the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services and enrolled in the program. If your family's income has been affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, or if you have had an income change since the beginning of the school year, you may qualify for free or reduced-price school meals. This will provide access to the benefits of the P-EBT program to your family. To review the eligibility requirements for free or reduced-price school meals, or to apply for them, please visit https://bit.ly/2z6nDlP.
\n
\nHowell Public Schools COVID-19 FAQ and Questions
\nWe continue to update our COVID-19 FAQ document as new questions are received, and answers are available. You can access the F.A.Q. at https://bit.ly/2yR440R. Additionally, if you have questions, we have launched a form for families to submit questions, which can be found at https://bit.ly/2y1qyeW.
\n
\nSincerely,
\nErin J. MacGregor, Ed.S.
\nSuperintendent
\nHowell Public Schools ","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_2","title":"COVID-19 Update 4/21/20 5:45 p.m.","content":"Dear Families,
\n
\nAs a way to celebrate the Howell Public Schools Class of 2020, we are hosting a Virtual Decision Week April 27-May 1. Follow the hashtags #HighlandersFutureReady #Idecided #collegeboundMI as we highlight the Seniors' decisions and post-secondary education plans on social media. All students and staff are invited to take part in a virtual spirit week. Share your spirit day photos or videos on social media using #HighlandersFutureReady or email them to hhssocialmediaclass@howellschools.com. To view the Spirit Week days, please visit https://bit.ly/2VNUKTa. 
\n
\nAnother way we plan to celebrate our Seniors is by providing each member of the Class of 2020 from both Howell High School and Innovation Academy, a lawn sign celebrating their accomplishments. The signs have been ordered, and we are working on a plan to safely distribute them once they arrive.
\n
\nI would also like to take a moment to honor our administrative professionals since tomorrow is Administrative Professional's Day. Day in and day out, regardless of the circumstances, our administrative professionals are there to support our students, families, and staff. Their commitment to the schools and our district has been reinforced time and time again as we collectively navigate the current situation. Please join me in sending a big virtual thank you to all of our administrative professionals.   
\n
\nMeal Distribution Returns to Howell High School 
\nBeginning next Monday, April 27, the district will resume distributing meal kits. The kits will be distributed each Monday through June 1. The distribution will take place from 4 p.m. to 6 p.m. in the circle drive on the north side of Howell High School. For families who lack transportation to pick up a meal kit, delivery will be available. To request delivery, please visit http://bit.ly/2vZoHa2. All requests for delivery will need to be submitted weekly and must be received by 2 p.m. on Sunday. This will allow our Food Service and Transportation Departments to plan for the deliveries. After 2 p.m., the form will not accept responses until Monday afternoon when families can request delivery for the next week. 
\n
\nResources from our School Counselors
\nOur school counselors continue to update their Resources for Families document as additional resources become available. You can view the Resources for Families document at https://bit.ly/2vMY9sr. Additionally, our counselors are available to support students during this time, and their email addresses are included in the Resources for Families document. Lastly, our counselors have compiled tips to help parents support their students as they learn from home, which can be viewed at https://bit.ly/2XUXkJE.
\n
\nTechnology Support
\nIf your family is in need of a device for remote learning or if you have other technology-related questions, support is available by calling 314-635-0638 Monday through Friday between 9:00 a.m. - 4:00 p.m. We ask that you only request a loaner device if your family is truly in need of one so that we can distribute devices as quickly and efficiently as possible to those who do not currently have a home device. Following the Governor's Stay at Home Order, technology support is only available remotely.
\n
\nAs always, I am so grateful for all of your support and understanding during this time.
\n
\nSincerely,
\nErin J. MacGregor, Ed.S.
\nSuperintendent
\nHowell Public Schools","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_3","title":"COVID-19 Update 4/16/20 5:45 p.m.","content":"Dear Families,
\n
\nI want to thank everyone who took part in my Virtual Coffee Chat today. The chat provided an excellent opportunity to have two-way conversations around the district's COVID-19 response and plans moving forward. I plan to offer additional opportunities like the Virtual Coffee Chat for stakeholders to engage in these conversations between now and the end of the school year. As dates are finalized, they will be posted on the district's website and shared in these updates.
\n
\nPandemic Electronic Benefit Transfer Program
\nRecently the State of Michigan announced that it has received approval for a program that will provide nutritious food to children affected by school closing due to COVID-19.  The Pandemic Electronic Benefit Transfer Program (P-EBT) will provide food assistance to families of students ages five-eighteen who receive free or reduced-price school meals. Qualifying families will receive $193.80 per child for the months of March and April, and $182.40 per child for the months of May and June combined. If your family's income has been affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, or if you have had an income change since the beginning of the school year, you may qualify for free or reduced-price school meals. This will provide access to the benefits of the P-EBT program to your family. To review the eligibility requirements for free or reduced-price school meals, or to apply for them, please visit https://bit.ly/2z6nDlP.
\n
\nStudent Safety During Remote Learning
\nIn response to the public health crisis, the Governor issued Executive Order 2020-35 on April 2, 2020, which ordered the suspension of in-person K-12 instruction for the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year. The Executive Order went on to detail requirements for school districts to continue to provide K-12 education utilizing alternative modes of instruction, including, but not limited to, online learning and virtual instruction. Howell Public Schools is complying with the order by providing continued instruction to our students via online learning and virtual instruction, including video-conferencing. While the district is implementing measures to ensure video-conferencing occurs in a secure and controlled environment, no method of virtual instruction using the Internet provides absolute security. In the event a security breach occurs, the district will address the situation immediately and notify law enforcement when necessary.  
\n
\nNext Meal Distribution is Monday, April 20
\nThe next meal distribution through our partnership with The Salvation Army will be on Monday, April 20. The Salvation Army will distribute pantry boxes containing breakfasts, lunches, and snacks. The distribution will take place from 4 pm to 6 pm at The Salvation Army Warehouse at 3600 East Grand River Ave., Howell. Families must provide a student's school I.D. or proof of Howell residency. 
\n
\nTechnology Support
\nIf your family is in need of a device for remote learning or if you have other technology-related questions, support is available by calling 314-635-0638 Monday through Friday between 9:00 a.m. - 4:00 p.m. We ask that you only request a loaner device if your family is truly in need of one so that we can distribute devices as quickly and efficiently as possible to those who do not currently have a home device. Following the Governor's Stay at Home Order, technology support is only available remotely.
\n
\nSummer Kids Kare Interest Form
\nTo help the district plan for its Summer Kids Kare Program, should we be able to offer it, we would like any families interested in utilizing this program to complete a short form, which can be found at https://bit.ly/2yi3jh2. Completing the form does not register your child(ren) for the program or guarantee a spot in the program, but will allow our staff to plan for staffing and to contact you when registration is open.
\n
\nHowell Public Schools COVID-19 FAQ and Questions
\nAs additional questions and answers are available we continue to update our COVID-19 FAQ document as new questions are received, and answers are available. You can access the F.A.Q. at https://bit.ly/2yR440R. Additionally, if you have questions, not answered in the F.A.Q. we have launched a form for families to submit questions, which can be found at https://bit.ly/2y1qyeW. 
\n
\nI cannot reiterate enough how thankful I am for your continued support and understanding as we shift to at-home learning and navigate the changing landscape of this situation.  
\n
\nSincerely,
\nErin J. MacGregor, Ed.S.
\nSuperintendent
\nHowell Public Schools","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_4","title":"COVID-19 Update 4/14/20 5:45 p.m.","content":"Dear Families,
\n
\nIn so many ways, the current situation has united our community as we have seen groups coming together to support one another. To support healthcare workers in the area, members of our high school robotics team, the S.C.O.T.S. Bots, have been using their personal 3-D printers to create N95 masks. The S.C.O.T.S. Bots have already created and donated 400 masks. Additionally, they have reached out to the other robotics teams in the Livingston County Robotics Alliance to ask them to begin creating masks as well. I am so proud of the students' initiative to provide much needed personal protective gear to hospital staff.
\n
\nSummer Kids Kare Interest Form
\nTo help the district plan for its Summer Kids Kare Program, should we be able to offer it, we would like any families who would be interested in utilizing this program to complete a short form, which can be found at https://bit.ly/2yi3jh2. Completing the form does not register your child(ren) for the program or guarantee a spot in the program, but will allow our staff to plan for staffing and to contact you when registration is open.
\n
\nNext Meal Distribution is Monday, April 20
\nThe next meal distribution through our partnership with The Salvation Army will be on Monday, April 20. The Salvation Army will distribute pantry boxes containing breakfasts, lunches, and snacks. The distribution will take place from 4 pm to 6 pm at The Salvation Army Warehouse at 3600 East Grand River Ave., Howell. Families must provide a student's school I.D. or proof of Howell residency. For families who lack transportation, The Salvation Army will offer delivery; however, delivery slots are limited. To request delivery, please visit https://bit.ly/2R4VTE6.  
\n
\nHowell Public Schools COVID-19 FAQ and Questions
\nWe continue to update our COVID-19 FAQ document as new questions are received, and answers are available. You can access the F.A.Q. at https://bit.ly/2yR440R. It is also posted under COVID-19 Resources HowellSchools.com/COVID-19. Additionally, if you have questions, we have launched a form for families to submit questions, which can be found at https://bit.ly/2y1qyeW. This is also posted under COVID-19 Resources on HowellSchools.com/COVID-19.
\n
\nVirtual Coffee Chat is Thursday, April 16
\nDon't forget that I will be holding a Virtual Coffee Chat this Thursday, April 16, from 11 a.m. to 12 p.m. During the chat, I will provide updates on our response to the COVID-19 situation and answer any questions that district stakeholders have about our plans moving forward. We will use the Zoom platform for this chat. You can access the Virtual Coffee Chat at https://bit.ly/2UUOoSz with the password 9Ew3Xq.
\n
\nTechnology Support
\nIf your family is in need of a device for remote learning or if you have other technology-related questions, support is available by calling 314-635-0638 Monday through Friday between 9:00 a.m. - 4:00 p.m. We ask that you only request a loaner device if your family is truly in need of one so that we can distribute devices as quickly and efficiently as possible to those who do not currently have a home device. Following the Governor's Stay at Home Order, technology support is only available remotely.  
\n
\nAs always, thank you for your continued support and understanding as we navigate the current situation as a district and community.
\n
\nSincerely,
\nErin J. MacGregor, Ed.S.
\nSuperintendent
\nHowell Public Schools","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_5","title":"COVID-19 Update 4/9/20 5:45 p.m.","content":"Dear Families,
\n
\nOne of the goals that we have set as a district is to find ways to celebrate our students during the time that our buildings are closed. With that in mind, I would like to take a moment to celebrate some Howell High School students who were selected for this year’s Art Scholarship Alert Exhibition sponsored by the Lansing Art Gallery. This is a juried show and scholarship competition that accepts student submissions from nine counties. This year, Sophomore Lydia Garcelon was selected as the Grade 10 Portfolio Award Winner and has her entire portfolio on display. Additionally, Junior, Felecia Berendt, Senior Alex Lam, Sophomore Hannah Porta, and Senior Kendall Weinburger also have artwork on display. Since the gallery is currently closed, they have created a virtual show with all of the artwork. You can access the virtual show at https://bit.ly/2xgnVpE. 
\n
\nVirtual Coffee Chat Next Thursday
\nOn Thursday, April 16, 2020, from 11 a.m. to 12 p.m., I will be hosting a Virtual Coffee Chat. During the chat, I will share updates about the district’s response to COVID-19, starting with the initial closure and running through the current time. There will also be an opportunity for stakeholders to ask any questions they may have about the current situation. You can access the Virtual Coffee Chat at https://bit.ly/2UUOoSz with the password 9Ew3Xq.
\n
\nHowell Public Schools COVID-19 FAQ
\nWe know there are lots of questions and not as many answers as we would like at this time. However, we are committed to answering as many questions as we can. We have created a FAQ that has answers to some of the most frequently asked questions. You can access the FAQ at https://bit.ly/2yR440R. It is also posted under COVID-19 Resources HowellSchools.com/COVID-19. Additionally, if you have questions, we have launched a form for families to submit questions, which can be found at https://bit.ly/2y1qyeW. This is also posted under COVID-19 Resources on HowellSchools.com/COVID-19.
\n
\nMeal Distribution Information
\nWe have partnered with The Salvation Army to continue providing meals to our families in need during this time. On Monday, April 13, The Salvation Army will distribute pantry boxes containing breakfasts, lunches, and snacks. The distribution will take place from 4 p.m. to 6 p.m. at The Salvation Army Warehouse is at 3600 East Grand River Ave., Howell. Families must provide a student’s school ID or proof of Howell residency.
\n
\nAthletic Facilities and Playgrounds are Closed
\nFor the duration of Governor Whitmer’s Stay at Home Order, all Howell Public Schools athletic facilities and playgrounds are closed. While we know the importance of maintaining a healthy lifestyle and exercise during this time, we are concerned about groups gathering and not practicing safe social distancing. In the end, this will help keep our students, families, and community safe.
\n
\nDistrict Issued Chromebook Technology Support
\nFollowing the Governor’s Stay at Home Order, Technology support is available by calling 314-635-0638 Monday through Friday between 9 a.m. and 4 p.m. 
\n
\nSincerely,
\n
\nErin J. MacGregor, Ed.S.
\nSuperintendent
\nHowell Public Schools","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_6","title":"COVID-19 Update 4/7/20 5:45 p.m.","content":"Dear Families,
\n
\nLast Friday, the Howell Board of Education met remotely to review our Continuity of Learning Plan and to make a minor revision to our policy regarding the number of on-line classes a student can take at one time. The Continuity of Learning Plan outlines how we plan to provide our current curriculum in an alternative way. As outlined in Governor Whitmer’s Executive Order, we submitted our plan to the Livingston Educational Service Agency for review, and I am happy to share that it has been approved. We have posted the plan on HowellSchools.com/COVID-19 under “Resources.” We are on track to launch this plan on Monday, April 13. Your child’s school will be sharing more about how the curriculum will be provided in the coming days.
\n
\nSupporting Kids During the Closure
\nWith the Governor ending in-person teaching and learning for the remainder of the school year, we know children may have concerns, anxiety, and several other feelings. Each child is different, and this change will affect them differently. Our school counselors have created a list of five tips to help parents navigate emotional conversations around this with their child, which can be found at https://bit.ly/34kn2s1. If you need to contact your child’s school counselor, you can find their email addresses at https://bit.ly/2QGLoqD. 
\n
\nPantry Boxes Available Monday, April 13 
\nWe have partnered with The Salvation Army to continue providing meals to our families in need during this time. On Monday, April 13, The Salvation Army will distribute pantry boxes containing breakfasts, lunches, and snacks. The distribution will take place from 4 p.m. to 6 p.m. at The Salvation Army Warehouse at 3600 East Grand River Ave., Howell. Families must provide a student’s school ID or proof of Howell residency. For families who lack transportation, The Salvation Army will offer delivery; however, delivery slots are limited. To request delivery, please visit https://bit.ly/2R4VTE6.  
\n
\nMHSAA Winter and Spring Sports Update
\nLast week, the Michigan High School Athletic Association (MHSAA) announced that it had canceled the remainder of the 2019-20 Winter and Spring sports seasons. You can read the announcement from the MHSSA at https://bit.ly/2JNIooA. 
\n
\nBond Project Update
\nDuring this time, the district continues to plan for the bond projects that are scheduled to take place this summer. However, being able to complete these projects is largely dependent on circumstances out of our control. Depending on how long things like the Governor’s Stay at Home Order remain in place, and the availability of workers and materials, some of these projects may need to be pushed back. While we have not given up hope that we can complete these projects this summer, I felt it was important to share that some work may be delayed. I will keep you updated as we have more information and a clearer picture of what work may or may not be completed.
\n
\nDistrict Issued Chromebook Technology Support
\nTechnology support for school-issued Chromebooks is available by calling 314-635-0638 Monday through Friday between 9 a.m. and 4 p.m. For the immediate future, and following the Governor’s Stay at Home Order, on-site tech support has been discontinued. 
\n
\nAs always, thank you for the continued support during this time. 
\n
\nSincerely,
\nErin J. MacGregor, Ed.S.
\nSuperintendent
\nHowell Public Schools","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_7","title":"COVID-19 Update 4/2/20 5:45 p.m.","content":"Dear Families,
\n
\nI know all of us are still processing this morning’s announcement that in-person teaching and learning will not be occurring for the remainder of the 2019-20 school year. As I shared earlier, this does not mean that teaching and learning will not occur, it will just look very different. As we work to finalize our plans to move to remote learning that will advance our current curriculum, we will continue to keep you updated. We know there will be bumps along the way, but we are committed to doing our absolute best to support all students. This will be new to all of us, and we appreciate your patience, support, and understanding as we pivot to this new way of learning.
\n
\nAthletic Facilities and Playgrounds are Closed
\nFor the duration of Governor Whitmer’s Stay at Home Order, all Howell Public Schools athletic facilities and playgrounds are closed. While we know the importance of maintaining a healthy lifestyle and exercise during this time, we are concerned about groups gathering and not practicing safe social distancing. In the end, this will help keep our students, families, and community safe.  
\n
\nPick-up of Items from School Buildings
\nWith today’s announcement from Governor Whitmer, we know that many students and families have questions about picking up items from our buildings. This is allowed under Governor Whitmer’s order. We are working on a plan to allow for this while following social distancing and other precautions. As soon as we have finalized this plan, we will share it with families. 
\n
\nNew Meal Distribution Process
\nWe have partnered with The Salvation Army to continue providing meals to our families in need during this time. On Monday, April 6, The Salvation Army will distribute pantry boxes that contain breakfasts, lunches, and snacks. The distribution will take place from 4 p.m. to 6 p.m. at The Salvation Army Warehouse at 3600 East Grand River Ave., Howell. Families must provide a student’s school ID or proof of Howell residency. To learn more, please visit https://bit.ly/2QNSBVV. For families who lack transportation, The Salvation Army will offer delivery. To request delivery, please visit https://bit.ly/2R4VTE6.  
\n
\nLinks to Student Email and Google Resources
\nTo help students quickly access their student email and other Google Resources, we have created a page on our website at https://bit.ly/2wQwpUe with links to the most commonly used Google links. 
\n
\nDistrict Issued Chromebook Technology Support
\nTechnology support for school-issued Chromebooks is available by calling 314-635-0638 Monday through Friday between 9 a.m. and 4 p.m. For the immediate future, and following the Governor’s Stay at Home Order, on-site tech support has been discontinued. 
\n
\nI cannot say this enough, thank you to all of our teachers, administrators, staff members, and families for the continued understanding and patience during this difficult time. As I shared in my communication this afternoon, we are heartbroken that we will end the school year without students in our buildings. However, Highlander Nation is strong, and we will persevere. 
\n
\nSincerely,
\n
\nErin J. MacGregor, Ed.S
\nSuperintendent
\nHowell Public Schools","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_8","title":"COVID-19 Update 4/2/20 1:10 p.m.","content":"Dear Families,
\n
\nToday, Thursday, April 2, 2020, Governor Whitmer announced the suspension of in-person instruction for all K-12 schools in the State of Michigan for the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year. I know I speak for our Board of Education, our teachers, administrators, and staff members when I say that we are heartbroken that we will end the school year without students in our buildings. However, Highlander Nation is strong, and we will persevere. 
\n
\nAs we navigate these unprecedented times, the safety and well-being of our students, families, and staff has and will continue to be our top priority. From ensuring our students and families have nutritious meals to our staff maintaining a connection with our students, I am proud of how our district team and community have come together to face this challenge. We will continue to support our students and families, and we will make it through this together.
\n
\nTo this end, our goals for the remainder of this school year are as follows: 1) maintain a strong connection to each student and family to ensure their mental and physical health is cared for 2) to the greatest extent possible, advance our current curriculum and 3) provide opportunities for students, families, and staff to celebrate all it means to be a Highlander. 
\n
\nFor the next week, we will continue providing at-home learning options for our students. During this time, the work will remain optional and ungraded. Additionally, district leadership will be addressing some minor changes to district policy to allow for online learning. Beginning on April 13, we will begin the process of providing new learning materials that will advance our current curriculum. We know this will look and feel different than what we are used to and know there will be challenges. However, we are committed to doing all that we can to ensure students continue to make academic gains during this time. 
\n
\nIn a typical school year, there are several end of the year celebrations that occur. From graduation to awards ceremonies and field days, each is special in its own way. It is not lost on me or any members of our team how upsetting missing these events will be for students, especially members of the Howell High School Class of 2020. While I cannot say how we will do it, you have my word that we will find ways to honor our students. We have a process in place at each level (elementary, middle, and high) to gather feedback and explore options. Our buildings will share more information in future communications. 
\n
\nI know that you have more questions than I have answers at this time. My team and I are working almost around the clock to find those answers and share them as they are available. As we adapt to this very fluid situation, I appreciate your patience and understanding. In the meantime, please continue to monitor HowellSchools.com/COVID-19 and your email for updates. Lastly, and I cannot say this enough, thank you to all of our staff who continue to do what is best for students during this time, and thank you to each of you for your continued support, understanding, and patience. We must continue to respond with courage and optimism and we must lift one another up. It will take all of us. Together we are #OneHowell.
\n
\nSincerely,
\n
\nErin J. MacGregor, Ed.S.
\nSuperintendent
\nHowell Public Schools","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_9","title":"COVID-19 Update 3/31/20 5:45 p.m.","content":"Dear Families,
\n
\nWhile these emails are intended to share important information about our response to the current COVID-19 outbreak, I also think it is essential for us to take a break and catch our breath. Creating the video below was in the works well before COVID-19 became a household word. Finishing the video was delayed, but it was worth the wait. It brought a smile to my team during a recent meeting, and I hope it brings one to yours as well. 
\n
\n
\n
\nRumor of Upcoming Executive Order from Governor Whitmer
\nAs you may have heard, there is a rumor circulating that Governor Whitmer is going to announce an executive order that will close all Michigan K-12 school buildings for the remainder of the year and shift instruction online. While nothing has been confirmed, we have been planning for an announcement like this. However, we receive these updates at the same time as the rest of the state, and until we receive the official news and can review the executive order, we cannot finalize our plans. We appreciate your patience as we wait to see how this will play out, but please know that we are ready to act quickly once we have the official directives from the Governor’s office. 
\n
\nNew Meal Distribution Process
\nWe have partnered with The Salvation Army to continue providing meals to our families in need during this time. On Monday, April 6, The Salvation Army will distribute pantry boxes that contain breakfasts, lunches, and snacks. The distribution will take place from 4 p.m. to 6 p.m. at The Salvation Army Warehouse at 3600 East Grand River Ave., Howell. Families must provide a student’s school ID or proof of Howell residency. To learn more, please visit https://bit.ly/2QNSBVV.
\n
\nLinks to Student Email and Google Resources
\nTo help students quickly access their student email and other Google Resources, we have created a page on our website at https://bit.ly/2wQwpUe with links to the most commonly used Google links. 
\n
\nOnline Registration
\nWhile our Begindergarten and Kindergarten Registration event has been postponed, families can still register their child for Begindergarten and Kindergarten online at HowellSchools.com/KDG. The district will schedule a day in the future for incoming students and their families to visit the students’ new school and to turn in any required paperwork needed to complete the enrollment process. Additionally, even though our Registration Office is closed, any new student can register online at HowellSchools.com/Enroll. For those who register online, we will collect the required paperwork needed to complete the enrollment process. 
\n
\nDistrict Issued Chromebook Technology Support
\nTechnology support for school-issued Chromebooks is available by calling 314-635-0638 Monday through Friday between 9 a.m. and 4 p.m. For the immediate future, and following the Governor’s Stay at Home Order, on-site tech support has been discontinued. 
\n
\nPlease continue to monitor HowellSchools.com/COVID-19 for updated information.
\n
\nSincerely, 
\nErin J. MacGregor, Ed.S.
\nSuperintendent
\nHowell Public Schools
","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_10","title":"COVID-19 Update 3/26/20 5:45 p.m.","content":"Dear Families,
\n
\nI hope this update finds you doing well. While there are many unknowns and what if’s regarding the current situation, one well-known thing is that Highlander Nation is strong and proud. I have really enjoyed watching our families and students participate in this week’s At-Home Spirit Week. It has also been wonderful to watch neighbors helping each other, and I have been overwhelmed by the number of community members and staff members who have reached out to see how they can continue to support our families during this difficult time. 
\n
\nClass of 2020 Local Scholarship Update
\nThe deadline for members of the Howell High School Class of 2020 to apply for local scholarships has been extended to Thursday, April 9. If the scholarship application posted on the website has no mailing or email address or if it indicates it should be submitted to the counseling office, please email the completed application to Mrs. Patritto at patritts@howellschools.com. If there is an email or mailing address on the scholarship application, please follow the deadline dates and apply as directed. Any questions that seniors have can be directed to Mrs. O’Connor (oconnorl@howellschools.com) or Mrs. Patritto.
\n
\nMHSAA Extends Suspension of Activities
\nThe MHSAA has extended its suspension of activities in all sports for all seasons through Monday, April 13, to fall in line with Gov. Gretchen Whitmer’s school closure and “stay home, stay safe” orders to deter the spread of COVID-19. All athletic activities to be halted include practices, scrimmages, and competitions/games, as well as strength training, conditioning, and any other organized sessions and events in all MHSAA in-season and out-of-season sports.
\n
\nDistrict Issued Chromebook Technology Support
\nTechnology support for school-issued Chromebooks is available by calling 314-635-0638 Monday through Friday between 9 a.m. and 4 p.m. For the immediate future, and following the Governor’s Stay at Home Order, on-site tech support has been discontinued. 
\n
\nMeals For Families During Required Closure
\nPlease remember that on Monday, March 30, from 4 to 6 p.m., our Food Service Department will be providing meal kits to district families who need them. The kits will contain both breakfast and lunch items for the week. The meal kits will be available for pick-up from 4 to 6 p.m. in the circle driveway on the north side of Howell High School (near the rock). Weekend Survival Kits will also be handed out during the meal distribution on Monday, March 30. The district will deliver meal kits to families who are unable to secure transportation to pick up or who cannot make it during the scheduled time. If you need a meal kit delivered, please visit http://bit.ly/2vZoHa2. Beginning on Monday, April 6, we will be partnering with local agencies to distribute meals. We will provide more information on the location and hours as we get closer to this date.
\n
\nI would be remiss If I did not once again thank each of you and all of our outstanding staff for the continued support and understanding regarding the current situation. We will get through this together. Please continue to monitor our website for information and resources at HowellSchools.com/COVID-19. 
\n
\nSincerely,
\nErin J. MacGregor, Ed.S.
\nSuperintendent
\nHowell Public Schools","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_11","title":"COVID-19 Update 3/24/20 6:45 p.m.","content":"
COVID-19 Update - Executive Order #2020-21\n
Temporary requirement to suspend activities that are not necessary to sustain or protect life.
\n
\n\n
The order requires each individual living within the State of Michigan to stay at home or at their place of residence to the maximum extent feasible. There are a few exceptions to this order in relation to employment. In part, the order states that “no entity shall...conduct operations that require workers to leave their homes or places of residence except to the extent that those workers are necessary to sustain or protect life or to conduct minimum basic operations.” Moreover, those who are permitted to leave their home must adhere to social distance measures. The executive order also requires the school district to specify in writing the workers designated as either “critical infrastructure workers” or “workers necessary to conduct minimum basic operations”. The workers in the school district meeting these definitions are:
\n
\n\n\n    
\n    
Childcare workers supporting Emergency Overflow Childcare Programs.
\n    
\n    \n    \n    
\n    
Food service, transportation employees and volunteers involved in distributing food to economically disadvantaged families.
\n    
\n    \n    \n    
\n    
District Office and Building staff whose in-person presence is strictly necessary to allow the operation to maintain the value of inventory and equipment, ensure security, process transactions, or facilitate the ability of others to work remotely: Board of Education, Superintendent, Executive Assistant to the Superintendent, Human Resources staff, Business, Finance, and Payroll staff, Technology staff, Public Relations Director, Instructional Services staff, Operations, Maintenance, and Custodial staff, and Building Principals.
\n    
\n    \n    \n\n
This order took effect on March 24, 2020, at 12:01 a.m., and continues through April 13, 2020, at 11:59 p.m. 
\n
\n\n
All other workers must work remotely during the time period of this order. If any workers not permitted to be on-site need access to a district facility, he or she must get approval in writing from the Superintendent.","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_12","title":"COVID-19 Update 3/24/20 5:45 p.m.","content":"Dear Families,
\n
\nYesterday, our outstanding staff met virtually to continue to plan at-home and alternative learning options for our students. As we have shared before, these options are not meant to replace the high-quality instruction that our teachers provide each day in their classrooms, but rather to keep students engaged in the learning process during this time. For the near future, these at-home and alternative learning options will continue to be optional and ungraded. I would like to thank all of our teachers, administrators, and staff who are working to support students during this time.
\n
\nSocial-Emotional Supports 
\nThe current events happening in our world can be scary for both children and adults. During this time, we know that some students may be in need of social and emotional support. To support our students, our school counselors are available by email if a student needs to talk to them. You can find their email addresses at https://bit.ly/2QGLoqD. Additionally, our counselors continue to update their local resources and support documents, which can be viewed at https://bit.ly/2vMY9sr. 
\n
\nHowell Carnegie Library Resources
\nEven though the Howell Carnegie Library is currently closed, all of our students in grades begindergarten through twelfth grade can still access the vast online resources the library offers, using their student ID number as their alternative library card. These resources include e-books, audiobooks, and more. To learn more about accessing these materials, please visit https://bit.ly/2QFcyOj. 
\n
\n2020 Census
\nWhile this is not necessarily a COVID-19 update, I did want to touch on the 2020 Census. Completing the Census is critical as it helps determine federal education funding for our district and county. You can complete the Census online at https://bit.ly/2wrcWt2. It typically takes less than 10 minutes to complete the Census, and you can complete the Census even if you have not yet received your official Census letter in the mail. 
\n
\nDistrict Issued Chromebook Technology Support
\nTechnology support for school-issued Chromebooks is available by calling 314-635-0638 Monday through Friday between 9 a.m. and 4 p.m. For the immediate future, and following the Governor’s Stay at Home Order, on-site tech support has been discontinued. 
\n
\nPlease remember that beginning today, district updates on the current situation will be issued each Tuesday and Thursday. If there are any urgent updates, we will share those as they are available. Also, please continue to monitor our website for information and resources at HowellSchools.com/COVID-19. 
\n
\nSincerely,
\nErin J. MacGregor, Ed.S.
\nSuperintendent
\nHowell Public Schools","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_13","title":"COVID-19 Update 3/23/20 3:15 p.m.","content":"Dear Families,
\n
\nThis morning, Governor Whitmer issued a Stay at Home Order for the State of Michigan amid the ongoing COVID-19 Pandemic. The executive order goes into effect at 12:01 a.m. tomorrow, Tuesday, March 24, 2020, and runs through Monday, April 13, 2020, at 11:59 p.m. The order has extended the mandatory shut-down of all Michigan K-12 schools, including Howell Public Schools, through at least Monday, April 13, 2020. While we were hoping we could welcome students back on Monday, April 6, we have been preparing for the mandatory closure to be extended. 
\n
\nAt-home and Alternative Learning
\nFor the time being, our outstanding teachers will continue to share at-home and alternative learning options. These options are not meant to replace the high-quality teaching and learning that happens each day in our classrooms. These resources are intended to keep students engaged in the learning process during this time. As we have shared, the at-home and alternative learning materials are optional and will not be graded. Please know, we are actively planning for what the next steps in our at-home and alternative learning are should this closure extend beyond April 13.
\n
\nDistrict Issued Chromebook Technology Support
\nTechnology support for school-issued Chromebooks is available by calling 314-635-0638 Monday through Friday between 9 a.m. and 4 p.m. For the immediate future, and in accordance with the Governor’s Stay at Home Order, on-site tech support has been discontinued. 
\n
\nMeals For Families During Required Closure
\nAs previously communicated, on Monday, March 23, and Monday, March 30, from 4 to 6 p.m., our Food Service Department will be providing meal kits to district families who need them. The kits will contain both breakfast and lunch items for the week. The meal kits will be available for pick-up from 4 to 6 p.m. in the circle driveway on the north side of Howell High School (near the rock). The district will deliver meal kits to families who are unable to secure transportation to pick up or who cannot make it during the scheduled time. If you need a meal kit delivered, please click here. Beginning on Monday, April 6, we will be partnering with local agencies to distribute meals. We will provide more information on the location and hours as we get closer to this date.
\n
\nAs we navigate these unprecedented times together, we are committed to sharing updates with you. We will send general updates each Tuesday and Thursday. Urgent updates will be shared as needed. Also, please continue to monitor our website for information and resources at HowellSchools.com/COVID-19. Again, thank you for your continued support during these times.  
\n
\nSincerely,
\nErin J. MacGregor, Ed.S.
\nSuperintendent
\nHowell Public Schools","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_14","title":"COVID-19 Update 3/19/20 5:45 p.m.","content":"Dear Families,
\n
\nOur community continues to support our students and one another during these times. As we continue to hear about supports that are available, we will share them both by email and post them on HowellSchools.com/COVID-19.  
\n
\nWeekend Survival Kits 
\nWith schools currently closed, Weekend Survival Kits recognizes that many Highlanders may need extra support with food at home. On Friday, March 20, at 11 a.m. Weekend Survival Kits will be distributing food kits from the circle drive on the north side of Howell High School. These kits include items for breakfasts, lunches, and dinners. 
\n
\nAt-home Alternative Learning Options
\nEarlier this week, our buildings and teachers sent out various at-home and alternative learning options. These options are not meant to replace the high-quality teaching and learning that happens each day in our classrooms. These resources are intended to keep students engaged in the learning process during this time. As we have shared, the at-home and alternative learning materials are optional and will not be graded. While we hope to welcome our students back on April 6, we are actively planning for what teaching and learning may look like should the mandated shut-down extend past April 6.
\n
\nDistrict Issued Chromebook Technology Support
\nThe Howell Public Schools Technology Department will provide tech support for school-issued Chromebooks during the mandated shut-down. If a student in six through twelfth grade is having a problem with their Chromebook, they can come to the Technology Department located in the district’s administrative office Monday-Friday between the hours of 10 a.m. and 1 p.m. Following proper social distancing guidelines, a Technology Department employee will provide support for the device. Additionally, tech support for school-issued Chromebooks is available by calling 314-635-0638 Monday through Friday between 9 a.m. and 4 p.m. 
\n
\nTechnology Survey
\nAs we plan for at-home/alternative learning options during these unprecedented times, the district would like to gain an understanding of our students’ access to technology. If you have not already done so, please complete our short technology survey at https://forms.gle/voFnzK25ATNkUsC98. 
\n
\nAgain, thank you for your continued support, patience, and understanding as we adjust to a rapidly changing situation.
\n
\nSincerely,
\n
\nErin J. MacGregor, Ed.S.
\nSuperintendent
\nHowell Public Schools

\nCommunity Food Resources 
\nAs we shared yesterday, our food distribution had a much higher than expected demand. To meet the needs of our students, we have scheduled an additional meal pick-up tomorrow, Wednesday, March 18, from 4 to 6 p.m. Meals will be distributed from the circle drive on the north side of Howell High School. There will not be delivery service offered tomorrow. While we are not checking ID’s we do ask that only those families who genuinely need this meal support, take a meal kit. We will also have meal kit distributions on Monday, March 23, and Monday, March 30. Pick-up on those days will be from 4-6 p.m. at the high school circle drive. Delivery service will be offered on Monday, March 23, and Monday, March 30, to families who lack access to transportation to get to the high school. To request delivery, please visit http://bit.ly/2vZoHa2. 
\n
\nMany community organizations are also offering food and meal support during this time. The Salvation Army has activated a mobile lunch service, Bountiful Harvest is preparing meal boxes for students on free and reduced lunch, and Gleaners Community Food Bank’s Shared Harvest Pantry is open by appointment. 
\n
","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_16","title":"COVID-19 Update 3/16/20 5:00 p.m.","content":"\n
Dear Families,\n\n
\n\n
As we continue as a district and community to navigate and adapt to this very fluid situation, below are the most current updates we have. Things are rapidly changing at the local, state and national levels. Due to this, we must remain flexible and be ready to change course at any time. Howell Public Schools is committed to providing continued updates as we have them. Please continue to monitor HowellSchools.com/COVID-19 for the most update to date information. \n\n
\n\n
At Home/Alternative Learning Options\n
Today, our teachers met to discuss and plan for at-home/alternative learning options during the time that schools are closed due to Governor Whitmer’s Executive Order. The intent of the at-home/alternative learning options is to keep students engaged while school is out of session.  At this time, these opportunities will be optional and ungraded, but we do highly encourage students to participate. In the next day or two, you will be receiving information about the at-home/alternative learning options from your child’s school.\n\n
\n\n
Technology Survey\n
As we plan for at-home/alternative learning options during these unprecedented times, the district would like to gain an understanding of our students’ access to technology. Please complete our short technology survey at https://forms.gle/voFnzK25ATNkUsC98. \n\n
\n\n
Internet Service Providers Opening Up Networks\n
Comcast and Charter Spectrum have both announced that they are opening up their wireless HotSpots for free to the general public. Additionally, both Comcast and Charter Spectrum are offering free internet for 60 days for qualifying families. Lastly, some wireless providers have removed their data limits during this time. Please check with your wireless provider to see if they are removing their data limits. \n\n
\n\n
Second Meal Distribution Date Schedule\n
Due to a higher than expected demand, we ran out of meal kits today, March 16. Due to this, we have planned another meal kit distribution for Wednesday, March 18 from 4 to 6 p.m. in the circle drive on the north side of Howell High School (near the rock). This will be pick-up only distribution. We apologize for any inconvenience caused today. \n\n
\n\n
I cannot thank you enough for your continued support, patience, and understanding as we adjust to a rapidly changing situation. Please continue to monitor HowellSchools.com/COVID-19.\n\n
\n\n
Sincerely,\n\n
\n\n
Erin J. MacGregor, Ed.S.\n
Superintendent\n
Howell Public Schools \n\n

\n
\nAdditionally, we have arranged for a staff member to be at each of our school buildings today, Monday, March 16, from 4 to 6 p.m. to allow for the pick-up of personal items that may still be left at school. This will be the last opportunity for students/families to pick-up these items.","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_18","title":"COVID-19 Update 3/13/20 6:45 p.m.","content":"Dear Families,
\n
\nWe cannot thank you enough for your patience and understanding as we work through the many implications of yesterday’s order by Governor Whitmer to close all K-12 public schools through April 5. We are dedicated to providing timely and accurate updates regarding this rapidly evolving situation. It will take us longer to have answers to some questions than others, but please know that we are working as fast as we can to answer them all.
\n
\nMeals For Families During Required Closure
\nWe know that many families depend on school meals for access to healthy and nutritious food. On Monday, March 16, Monday, March 23, and Monday, March 30 from 4 to 6 p.m. our Food Service Department will be providing meal kits to any families who need them. The kits will contain both breakfast and lunch items for the week. The meal kits will be available for pick-up from 4 to 6 p.m. in the circle driveway on the north side of Howell High School (near the rock). The district will deliver meal kits to families who are unable to secure transportation to pick one up or who cannot make it during the pick-up time. If you need a meal kit delivered, please click here.
\n
\nAt-Home Learning Options
\nWe are working collaboratively and in full partnership with the Howell Education Association to develop at-home learning options during this time. On Monday, March 16, our teaching staff is meeting to develop short term at-home learning and enrichment opportunities to support our students during the time between now and Spring Break. At this time, these opportunities will be optional and ungraded, but we do highly encourage students to participate. Links to and information about these learning and enrichment opportunities will be shared with families early next week. Additionally, the district is planning for a more robust at-home learning experience should we be required to stay closed for a longer period of time. 
\n
\nAdditional Resources for Students and Families
\nAs we navigate through these unprecedented times we understand that some students may be struggling to understand the recent events. Our outstanding school counselors have put together a list of ways that families can help ease a child’s worry and anxiety around COVID-19. You can view these resources at http://bit.ly/2QaOjr1. 
\n
\nAdditionally, the school counselors have compiled a list of resources and community supports that can be found at http://bit.ly/2WcjXsk. 
\n
\nAthletic Update 
\nToday, the MHSAA directed all schools to suspended activities in all sports. The suspension of activities applies all three MHSAA seasons and is effective Monday, March 16 through at least Sunday, April 5 to fall in line with Gov. Gretchen Whitmer’s order that all schools close for the next three weeks in order to deter the spread of COVID-19. All athletic activities to be halted include practices, scrimmages, and competitions/games, as well as strength training, conditioning, and any other organized sessions and activities in all MHSAA in-season and out-of-season sports.
\n
\nAgain, thank you for your understanding and patience. It is greatly appreciated by our district staff who are working around the clock on these matters. If there are urgent updates over the weekend, we will be sure to send a communication to you. However, non-pressing matters may be delayed until Monday, as we hope to allow our staff to get some rest this weekend.
\n
\nSincerely,
\nErin J. MacGregor, Ed.S.
\nSuperintendent
\nHowell Public Schools

\n
\nWe have arranged for our school buildings to be open today, Friday, March 13, 2020, from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. for students and families to pick up personal belongings. If your child has medication at school that may be needed during this extended closure, please be sure to pick that up today as well. Students in grades 6-12 should be sure to pick-up their Chromebook and charger. Lastly, if your child has any food in their locker please be sure to remove it. 
\n
\nThis is a one day opportunity for access to obtaining these personal items.  Please be patient, understanding and kind to our limited staff who will be assisting you today so we can make sure that we get you your items as efficiently as possible.
\n
\nAs a district team, we are working through many items and trying to answer all questions as quickly as we can. We will continue to provide updates at HowellSchools.com/COVID-19 as they are available. Again, we greatly appreciate your continued understanding and patience as we work through this rapidly evolving situation. 
\n
\nThank you,
\nHowell Public Schools

","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_20","title":"Livingston County Schools Joint COVID-19 Letter 3/13/20 12:11 a.m.","content":"Dear Students, Parents, Staff and Community Members:
\n
\nClick here to view a .PDF of this update.
\n
\nMoments ago, Governor Gretchen Whitmer announced that in order to slow the spread of Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) in Michigan, she is ordering the closure of all K-12 school buildings, starting Monday, March 16 until Sunday, April 5. School buildings are scheduled to reopen on Monday, April 6.
\n
\nIn the interest of student and staff safety we have decided to close all school buildings in Livingston County beginning Friday, March 13th.
\n
\nAs of tonight, the number of presumptive positive cases of COVID-19 in Michigan is 12. “This is a necessary step to protect our kids, our families, and our overall public health,” said Governor Whitmer. “I am working with partners across state government to ensure educators, parents, and students have the support they need during this time, and to ensure our children who rely on school for meals have access to food. I know this will be a tough time, but we’re doing this to keep the most people we can safe. I urge everyone to make smart choices during this time and to do everything they can to protect themselves and their
\nfamilies.”
\n
\n“Closing our K-12 school buildings is the responsible choice that will minimize the risk of exposure for children, educators, and families and mitigate the spread of coronavirus,” said Michigan State Superintendent Michael Rice. “The Department of Education will continue to work closely with our partners in state government to help our students and educators in each school district get through this time. This is about protecting the most people in Michigan.” Thank you for your attention and support regarding this important topic as safety is our number one priority.
\n
\nDr. R. Michael Hubert, Superintendent
\nLivingston Educational Service Agency
\n
\nErin MacGregor, Superintendent
\nHowell Public Schools
\n
\nDr. Greg Gray, Superintendent
\nBrighton Area Schools
\n
\nFowlerville Community Schools
\nWayne Roedel, Superintendent
\n
\nChuck Hughes, Superintendent
\nHartland Consolidated Schools
\n
\nRick Todd, Superintendent
\nPinckney Community Schools
\n
\n
\n","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_21","title":"Livingston County Schools Joint COVID-19 Letter 3/12/20 8:00 p.m.","content":"To view a .PDF of this update, please click here.
\n
\nDear Students, Parents, Staff and Community Members:
\n
\nThe coronavirus (COVID-19) situation and guidance are changing rapidly.  With the increased number of confirmed COVID-19 cases in the U.S., Livingston County Schools will continue to provide communication on the status of our school community.  The intent of this message is to update you on several important aspects of our district operations.
\n
\nWe remain committed to the safety of our students, staff, and school community. Our County Schools will continue to follow the guidance of our Governor, the Livingston County Health Department, the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services, the Michigan Department of Education, and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. 
\n
\nAccordingly, our County Schools will have a full day of school on Friday, March 13, 2020.  However, with the fluidity of the recommendations from the local, state, and federal health departments, it is possible that a long-term school closure could become a reality. Therefore, we recommend that students and staff take home personal items at the end of the school day tomorrow. This will also assist our custodial staff with their continued efforts to sanitize our facilities.
\n
\nIt is our collective intent to maintain as much of our school day operations until such time that it is not considered safe by health experts to conduct regular classes. 
\n
\nThank you for your attention and support regarding this important topic as safety is our number one priority.
\n
\nDr. R. Michael Hubert, Superintendent
\nLivingston Educational Service Agency
\n
\nErin MacGregor, Superintendent
\nHowell Public Schools
\n
\nDr. Greg Gray, Superintendent
\nBrighton Area Schools
\n
\nFowlerville Community Schools
\nWayne Roedel, Superintendent
\n
\nChuck Hughes, Superintendent
\nHartland Consolidated Schools
\n
\nRick Todd, Superintendent
\nPinckney Community Schools

We wanted to provide this update since we had communicated different information earlier this afternoon.
\n
\nAs this is a rapidly evolving and fluid situation, changes like this are happening often. We will be utilizing the district's COVID-19 webpage to provide updates. As updates such as this are posted, we will send an alert via our SMS text messaging system. If you have not opted-in to receive our SMS text messages, you may do so by texting \"Y\" to 67587 from your wireless device. You will receive the following reply: \"You're registered 4 SchoolMessenger notifications.\"
\n
\nAny major update or notification will be shared via email/phone/SMS text messaging.
\n
\nAgain, this is a rapidly changing and fluid situation. We will do our best to reply to emails and phone calls; however, responses may be delayed.","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_23","title":"Livingston County Superintendents Joint Update On COVID-19 3/11/20 ","content":"To view a .PDF of this update click here.
\n
\nDear Students, Parents, Staff and Community Members:
\n
\nToday, Governor Whitmer and representatives from the Michigan Department of Health & Human Services announced recommendations for keeping students and staff healthy while addressing the risks associated with the Coronavirus. We have been in close contact with the Livingston County Health Department, the Michigan Department of Education, and Governor Whitmer’s Office.
\n
\nOur immediate plan for mitigating the spread of COVID-19 in our communities while advancing student learning is based on three factors:
\n1. Avoiding unnecessary exposure of our staff and students to illness.
\n2. Working to the best of our ability to ensure the continuity of teaching and learning in Livingston County.
\n3. Protecting the health and well-being of our multigenerational community, especially those who are most vulnerable to illness.
\n
\nWith this in mind, we will enact the following measures related to events and programs scheduled outside of the regular school day beginning tomorrow (Thursday, March 12):
\n• All field trips are suspended until further notice.
\n• All school-sponsored travel is suspended until further notice.
\n• All assemblies and performances in our schools involving participation by the general public are suspended until further notice.
\n• All community meetings, community education programming (excluding before/after school childcare, preschool, and daycare programming), rentals, and gatherings scheduled to take place within our school facilities are suspended until further notice.
\n• All athletic events will continue in accordance with guidance issued by the Michigan High School Athletic Association (MHSAA). Updates will be posted at www.mhsaa.com.
\n• Any after-school activity consisting of a group of less than 100 people and an extension of the normal learning day (clubs, athletic practices, etc.) will continue as planned.
\n• All tours of school facilities will be suspended until further notice.
\n
\nAs we prepare for all possible scenarios, we are asking you to develop a plan for your family in the event schools were to close for an extended period of time. The Governor has declared a state of emergency, we are taking COVID-19 very seriously and hope that with your help, we can mitigate the spread of this virus in Livingston County. Please follow the recommendations to wash your hands, stay home when you are sick, and practice good hygiene.
\n
\nGovernor Whitmer said, \"Community mitigation strategies are designed to be implemented at the individual, organizational, and community levels. They apply to businesses, workplaces, schools, community organizations, health care institutions, and individuals of all ages, backgrounds, and health profiles; everyone has an important role to play.\"
\n
\nWe will continue to take any/all measures to keep our children, staff, and school community safe. The situation involving this health challenge is rapidly changing and we will update you as additional guidance is received. Thank you for your attention and support regarding this important topic as safety is our number one priority.
\n
\nDr. R. Michael Hubert, Superintendent
\nLivingston Educational Service Agency
\n
\nErin MacGregor, Superintendent
\nHowell Public Schools
\n
\nDr. Greg Gray, Superintendent
\nBrighton Area Schools
\n
\nFowlerville Community Schools
\nWayne Roedel, Superintendent
\n
\nChuck Hughes, Superintendent
\nHartland Consolidated Schools
\n
\nRick Todd, Superintendent
\nPinckney Community Schools","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_24","title":"Superintendent's Update On COVID-19 3/11/20","content":"
Dear Families,\n
\n\n
As you have likely heard, yesterday, March 10, Governor Whitmer announced that there are now two presumptive cases of the coronavirus (COVID-19) in Michigan. As the Governor shared, the samples have been sent to the CDC for confirmation. Both cases are in the metro-Detroit area, and those affected are receiving treatment. At this time, there are no confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Livingston County. Obviously, this is a very fluid and rapidly evolving situation. \n
\n\n
The other county superintendents and I have been in constant contact with the Livingston County Health Department. We were reassured that, at this time, we do not need to take any additional actions relating to COVID-19. We will remain in close contact with the Livingston County Health Department to check-in, receive updates, and ensure that each school district is following the same practices. \n
\n\n
While the Livingston County Health Department has indicated that our current cleaning procedures are adequate, out of an abundance of caution, we have developed a schedule with our custodial contractor for ongoing deep cleaning at each building. This will include the use of an electrostatic sprayer, that delivers disinfecting solutions to the front, back and sides of surfaces for superior coverage and enhanced germ protection.\n
\n\n
We will continue to work in partnership and take all directions relating to COVID-19 from our local, state and federal health experts. \n\nAgain, medical experts indicate that the best ways to prevent the spread of COVID -19 are the same recommendations for preventing the spread of the flu, which include:\n\n    
Avoiding close contact with people who are sick\n    
Avoiding touching your eyes, nose, and mouth\n    
Staying home when you are sick\n    
Covering your cough or sneeze with a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash\n    
Cleaning and disinfecting frequently touched objects and surfaces using a regular household cleaning spray or wipe\n    
Washing your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after going to the bathroom; before eating; and after blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing\n    \n\n
Please help us reinforce these practices by reviewing them with your child(ren) on a regular basis. In addition, until otherwise communicated, we ask students and adults to discontinue close contact (handshakes, etc.) with each other during our school activities.\n
\n\n
Lastly, we have created a page on our website to host our updates, resources from our health department, and a forthcoming summary of Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs). That page can be found at HowellSchools.com/COVID-19. Again, this is a very fluid and rapidly evolving situation and we are working with all appropriate local, state, and federal health officials on the matter. We will update you accordingly.\n
\n\n
Sincerely,\n
\n\n
Erin J. MacGregor, Ed.S.\n
Superintendent\n
Howell Public Schools","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_25","title":"Superintendent's Update On COVID-19 3/6/20","content":"We know that the Coronavirus (CONVID-19) is on the minds of many people. Please know that we are closely following developments regarding the Coronavirus (COVID-19). While there are no confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Livingston County or Michigan, we will follow the direction of the county and state health departments as it relates to COVID-19. To that end, this week, the superintendents of each of the county’s school districts met with officials from the Livingston County Department of Health & Human Services (DHHS). This meeting provided us with a better understanding of the current situation directly from public health officials and experts. Additionally, it provided an opportunity for DHHS staff to share what role schools should play in the county’s community response efforts. This joint meeting will ensure that each school district is approaching the response utilizing best practices in a consistent manner. Since we are the experts in education and not communicable diseases, we will continue to follow the advice of local, state, and federal health officials. Medical experts indicate that the best ways to prevent the spread of COVID -19 are the same recommendations for preventing the spread of the flu, which include
\n  
\n * Avoiding close contact with people who are sick
\n * Avoiding touching your eyes, nose, and mouth
\n * Staying home when you are sick
\n * Covering your cough or sneeze with a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash
\n * Cleaning and disinfecting frequently touched objects and surfaces using a regular household cleaning spray or wipe
\n 8 Washing your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after going to the bathroom; before eating; and after blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing
\n
\nPlease help us reinforce these practices by reviewing them with your child(ren) on a regular basis.
\n
\nAdditionally, the Livingston County Health Department has compiled resources and guidance regarding the Coronavirus on its website. You can find those resources by visiting http://bit.ly/3cAVySI. We will continue to keep you updated on this issue.","active":false,"disabled":false}],// required,
